title: Mana based champions have one disadvantage over energy based
body:
Mana refilling when being at base.

I just tested Lux in practice tools. Lvl 18 without items. It takes about 10 seconds to fill the mana which means you have to wait for such long time to be ready to play , when champions like zed or akali can play immediately.

Edit: tested with items: lvl 6 (doran's ring) - 11 seconds, lvl 18 with full items - 13 seconds.

Oh.
I thought I was the only one! When you recall your mana takes SO long to recharge like wtf!

One trick that I have seen people do to not wait in fountain so long. wait for your mana and/or health to fill up to roughly 8/10 of the bar, then simply walk to lane. It does depend on your champ’s mana regen, but for most champions by the time you get to lane your Health and Mana should be full

Though an interesting point, I can see why that advantage is had. Building up that pool for spammable abilities should take more time than energy based units who have to carefully calculate just how much energy they need for the combo they want to execute. If energy pools grew over the game I'm sure they'd have just the same problem.

The problem here is that unless you are an Akali spamming Qs or a Kennen using E with half of the energy bar, it's really difficult to run out of energy in any champion. They have more than enough for one rotation of their ablilties, and by the time their abilities are off CD, they already have almost all of their energy back. The only thing energy does for most champs that use it is preventing them from building a lot of CDR early on to have their important abilities quickly off CD in lane. Zed rushing CDR early on to have the shuriken on a 3.6s CD and the shadow on a 13.2s CD would be a fucking nightmare.

I almost never see one of these champs running out. For most of them, you could increase a bit their cooldowns and remove the energy mechanic, and that would be it. Keep in mind that I said most of them, energy is the only thing that keeps Akali from spamming 1Q every second.

Ironically, the best energy-like system in League is not in an energy champion, but in {{champion:68}} .

* You actually are able to burn out your resource bar without having to spam 3 rotations in a row, so you actually have to be careful.

* You get aditional benefits for keeping the resource bar on a delimited zone. That alone adds a lot of depth to that mechanic, and rewards resource management.
Also having actual cooldowns?
Also being able to farm up without having to back at all.
Explain please, why do you think it is stupid?

More than a mana vs energy champ think, I feel like it’s an unfair advantage to resourceless champions.

Technically that’s the tradeoff for energy champions (they gain the same % energy regen in fountain but they already have very high regen). They suck at prolonged combat where mana users prevail, but are better at short skirmishes early on.

Well, on the other hand, mana means you can have a larger pool and regeneration through items whereas total energy and energy regen can't be altered, (except with new PoM, but only the pool's size even then).

Also, when you checked for the level 18 with full items, what was the game time? I was under the impression after 20 mins or so the regen increases a good amount

Edit: just checked in practice tool, it took me 4 seconds to get to full mana from 0 with lux(minute 21, level 18). What is this post?
But unlike energy based champs mana champs can stay on the map for 40 minutes because they don't actually have a mana cost and their items give them thousands of mana

Between presence of mind, manaflow band, and biscuit/time warp tonic...there are literally 3/5 trees that give access to mana regeneration in lane.

It is ludicrous how little mana means to mages these days, unless you're Ryze (which is not even because of his mana costs, but because of how it's tied to his damage.)

Yeah, except that by taking mana regen or other mana bonus runes, you sacrifice other things like damage, utility, MS, healing, tenacity, magic shields, etc. In other words, energy champs and non-resource champs are at a severe advantage just in the rune tree alone by being able to focus on other advantages without needing to sacrifice resource management.

On paper what you say is true. In practice, 250 mana + 1% missing mana every 5s vs say 6 mpen/lethality after a dash, when considering that you can basically non-stop spam your spells, is kind of a negligible difference.

... the same is true of most energy-based champions because the regen is high enough that you can feasibly regain your entire bar in some scenarios, and they also all have a pretty easy way to regain energy by using their abilities correctly, which means they rarely run out. The only exception to this is akali i'd say, since she can only regain energy by hitting a champ with her spells, and she has some of the highest costs on the lowest cooldown.
